choices.text: It carries both motor and sensory fibres
It arises from the medullary part of brainstem
It has the root value C3 C4 and C5

questions.text: A 53-year-old visited the surgery OPD with the complaints of a small swelling over her neck on the right side for the past two months. She also complained of loss of appetite, severe weight loss in the past few months.  On examination it was found to be an enlargement of one of the deep cervical lymph nodes. Lymph node biopsy of her deep cervical nodes on the right side of her neck. Immediately following surgery, she complains of weakness in her right shoulder. On examination, her left shoulder droops and she is unable to raise the point of her shoulder. She does not feel any numbness in her shoulder, back, or neck. Which of the following statements is true about the nerve injured in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It passes through foramen magnum

 

Option C:

 

  • The spinal accessory nerve passes  from cervical region to cranial cavity through foramen magnum then accompanies the cranial part of accessory nerve and passes through jugular foramen and exits the cranial cavity.

 

 

  • The nerve injured in this case is the spinal accessory nerve. It innervates trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscle and receives proprioceptive fibres from trapezius. It does not have any cutaneous branches.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. While many nerves carry both motor and sensory fibers, the specific symptoms described suggest a primarily motor nerve involvement. The nerve most likely injured given these symptoms is the accessory nerve, which primarily carries motor fibers.

 

Option B. The  spinal component of the accessory nerve does not arise from the medullary part of the brainstem. It has a cranial component that originates from the medulla oblongata and a spinal component that originates from the upper cervical spinal cord (C1-C5). The cranial component quickly joins the spinal component, and it's the spinal part that innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid muscles.

 

Option D. The phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm, has the root values of C3, C4, and C5. The accessory nerve, as mentioned, has spinal roots from C1 to C5.

 

Educational objective:

 

  •  Spinal part of the accessory nerve ascends from the cervical spinal cord, enters the cranial cavity through the foramen magnum, and then exits the skull through the jugular foramen.

  • The injury described is consistent with damage to the accessory nerve, which would affect the trapezius muscle leading to the inability to raise the shoulder or maintain shoulder symmetry.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 413

questions.text: Which of the following lists comprises bones that are part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Clavicle, Fibula,  Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius

 

Option B.

 

  • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular system)
  • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular system)
  • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular system)
  • This list contains bones from appendicular skeletons only, hence it is answer.
  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial skeleton
    • Appendicular skeleton
  • All bones of axial & appendicular system are shown in below image

 

 

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia

 

  • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum

 

  • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Scapula (Shoulder Blade) is part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Occipital is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton.
  • Metacarpals are the bones in the hand, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Sternum (Breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons.

 

Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal

 

  • Ulna is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Radius is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Phalanges are the finger and toe bones, part of the appendicular skeleton.
  • Mandible (Lower Jawbone) is part of the axial skeleton.
  • Coxal (Hip Bone) is part of the pelvic girdle of the appendicular skeleton.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts:
    • Axial Skeleton
    • Appendicular Skeleton
      • Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle (Appendicular System)
      • Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb (Appendicular System)
      • Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton.
      • Radius is preaxial bone of forearm (Appendicular System)

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 66

choices.text: The structure swollen is the Parotid Gland
Parotid swelling are usually less painful
The Facial Nerve divides into five branches within Parotid Gland
Inability to close eye is due to paralysis of Orbicularis Oculi that is innervated by Facial Nerve

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presented with a complaint of rapidly growing painful swelling on the face below the right ear lobule. On examination the right ear lobule was found to be lifted by the swelling. There was inability to close the right eye, blow the cheek and angle of mouth deviated to left side. Which of the following statements is not true pertaining to the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Parotid swelling are usually less painful

 

Option B:

 

In the question which of the following is wrong has been asked and since  parotid swellings are painful, option B is wrong.

 

  • The fascial capsule of the parotid gland is derived from an investing layer of deep cervical fascia.

 

 

  • It blends with the epimysium of adjoining masseter muscle to form the parotidomasseteric fascia, which is unyielding hence even a small swelling will be severely painful.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The location of the swelling below the ear lobule and the associated facial nerve symptoms (inability to close the eye, deviation of the mouth) suggest that the swelling involves the parotid gland, which is also where the facial nerve (CN VII) is located.

 

Option C. The facial nerve divides into five main branches within the parotid gland: temporal, zygomatic, buccal, marginal mandibular, and cervical.

 

 

Option D. The inability to close the eye (lagophthalmos) in this patient is due to paralysis of the orbicularis oculi muscle, which is innervated by the facial nerve. Damage to the facial nerve can lead to paralysis of the muscles it innervates, including the orbicularis oculi.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  Parotid gland swellings are often less painful when they are due to chronic conditions like benign tumors or Sjogren's syndrome. However, acute infections or malignant growths in the parotid gland can be painful.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 504

questions.text: Identify the bone in given image forming a crucial part of the auditory ossicles chain for sound transmission?"
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Incus

 

Option B:

 

  • The given bone in the image is the ear ossicle - Incus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. MALLEUS: Head-articulates with body of incus to form saddle synovial joint. Handle -medial surface upper end receives tensor tympani insertion. Handle embedded in fibrous layer of tympanic membrane. Anterior process-anterior ligament of malleus, Lateral process- Anterior and posterior malleolar folds.

 

Option C. STAPES: Head articulate with incus to form ball and socket joint, Neck -insertion of stapedius and Anterior and posterior limbs connected by footplate of stapes-closes fenestra vestibule.

 

Option D. Vomer: It is unpaired bone, contributes to posteroinferior portion of nasal septum.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Body forms saddle synovial joint with incus, short process -ligament to fossa incudis and Long process-tip forms ball and socket synovial joint with head of stapes.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th edition pg 284

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the knee joint. Physical examination reveals warmth and tenderness around the affected joint, and imaging studies show joint space narrowing and bone erosion. Which of the following category of joint is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Freely Moveable Joint

 

Option C.

 

  • Knee joint is the type of diarthosis or synovial joint which is the example of freely moveable joint.
  • Synovial fluid is present in between articular surfaces.
  • In this case knee joint is involved which is classical example of synovial joint.
  • Synovial joints are filled with synovial fluid which is the lubricant that allows friction free joint movement.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):

 

  • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement.
  • An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull.
  • Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints, as they allow no movement.

 

Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:

 

  • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis.
  • It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage.
  • An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine.
  • While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement, they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Freely Moveable Joint:

 

  • It allows a wide range of movement. Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow.
  • They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid, which facilitates movement.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 88

questions.text: What is the nerve supply of the marked structure in the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Glossopharyngeal Nerve

 

Option C:

 

  • The pointed structure is a circumvallate papillae.

  • Nerve supply of tongue is shown in image:


 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The lingual nerve is a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (cranial nerve V3). It supplies general sensation (such as touch, pain, and temperature) to the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. However, it does not supply the circumvallate papillae.

 

Option B. The chorda tympani is a branch of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII). It carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue and also supplies parasympathetic fibers to the submandibular and sublingual glands. While it does carry taste sensations, these are not from the circumvallate papillae but from the anterior portion of the tongue.

 

Option D. The vagus nerve (cranial nerve X) is involved in many autonomic functions of the body and provides sensory innervation to a small area of the root of the tongue. However, it does not supply the circumvallate papillae.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • The glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX) provides sensory and taste sensation to the posterior one-third of the tongue, which includes the circumvallate papillae. These papillae are located at the back of the tongue and are innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve.

  • Glossopharyngeal nerve receives taste sensation from circumvallate papillae and posterior 1/3 tongue.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 145

questions.text: Patient undergoing treatment for Borderline tuberculoid leprosy presented with papular lesion on (frontal & maxillary area) forehead, nose extending bilateral to cheeks with sensory involvement. Which nerve is involved:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trigeminal nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • Sensory innervation of face is from ophthalmic, maxillary and mandibular division of trigeminal nerve, except the skin over the angle of mandible is from great auricular nerve, a branch from cervical plexus

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The Facial nerve, or seventh cranial nerve (CN VII), primarily controls the muscles of facial expression. It also provides some sensory function for the external ear and has parasympathetic fibers. While the Facial nerve does affect the facial region, its primary role is motor control rather than sensation. The patient's symptoms are more aligned with sensory involvement, which is less indicative of Facial nerve pathology.

 

Option C. The Transverse Cervical nerve arises from the cervical plexus, typically from the second and third cervical nerves. It provides sensation to the anterior neck. The distribution of the lesion in the patient does not align with the innervation territory of the Transverse Cervical nerve, which is focused on the neck area and not the face.

 

Option D. The Ventral ramus of the second cervical nerve (C2) forms part of the cervical plexus and contributes to the innervation of the neck. Similar to the Transverse Cervical nerve, the Ventral ramus of C2 is involved in innervating the neck area, not the facial regions described in the patient's symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Trigeminal nerve, also known as the fifth cranial nerve (CN V), is primarily responsible for sensation in the face. It has three branches: the ophthalmic (V1), maxillary (V2), and mandibular (V3) branches.

  •  The description of the lesions on the forehead, nose, and extending bilaterally to the cheeks correlates with the areas innervated by the Trigeminal nerve, specifically the ophthalmic and maxillary branches.

  • The sensory involvement further supports this, as the Trigeminal nerve is a key sensory nerve for the face.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg. 63

choices.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

 

Option B:

 

  • The “Plate” is the Hyaline Cartilage between the Shaft (Diaphysis) and End (Epiphysis) of a Long bone in Children and Adolescents.
  • The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.
  • In Adults it is replaced by an ossified “Epiphyseal Line”.

 

 

Explanation

 

Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone. The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity.

 

Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone.  While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis, it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation.

 

Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal, or medullary cavity, is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

choices.text: Maxillary Sinus
Sphenoidal Sinus
Frontal Sinus
Ethmoidal Sinus (middle)

questions.text: A 32-year-old female had complaints of nasal stuffiness, pain over her upper jaw. On examination there was tenderness over the right and left cheek bones. The below is the CT of the patient. All the following open into the probed space except?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Sphenoidal sinus

 

Option B:

 

  • The probed space is the middle meatus of the nasal cavity which is situated below the middle concha.
  • It receives the opening of maxillary, frontal, anterior ethmoidal and middle ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoid sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess situated above the superior concha.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The maxillary sinus drains into the nasal cavity via the maxillary ostium, which opens into the semilunar hiatus located in the middle meatus of the nasal cavity.

 

Option C. Frontal Sinus: The frontal sinus drains into the nasal cavity through the frontonasal duct, which opens into the middle meatus, typically in the region of the infundibulum.

 

Option D. Ethmoidal Sinus: The middle ethmoidal sinuses (or middle ethmoidal air cells) drain into the middle meatus of the nasal cavity, specifically into the ethmoid bulla. Top of Form

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Sphenoidal Sinus: The sphenoidal sinus opens into the sphenoethmoidal recess, which is located above the superior concha, not the middle meatus.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 565

choices.text: The Hyoid bone is a non-articulating bone
Hyoid is attached to Thyroid cartilage
Hyoid is positioned in Anterior midline of Neck
Greater horn of the Hyoid bone originates from the second Pharyngeal arch

questions.text: A 30-year-old male was admitted to ER following a traffic accident complaining of anterior neck pain. The patient stated that he was sitting in the back seat of an automobile with his seatbelt unfastened at the time of a head-on collision. As a result, he hit his head on the edge of the front seat, which forced his neck back. Neck movements were unrestricted but the patient was extremely agitated because of conspicuous neck pain. In addition, his hyoid bone was tender during palpation. No loss of consciousness had occurred, and the Glasgow Coma Scale was 15/15. The patient’s pupils were equal and reactive to light, and no midline bony tenderness was detected in the cervical spine upon palpation. Anteroposterior and lateral cervical radiographs obtained on admission showed normal cervical spine, and neck structures. A lateral cervical radiograph demonstrated a slight fracture line and displacement of the hyoid bone. Which of the following statements is incorrect pertaining to the above case?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Greater horn of the Hyoid bone originates from the second Pharyngeal arch

 

Option D:

 

  • Greater horn of the hyoid bone originates from the third pharyngeal arch.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hyoid bone does not articulate with the surrounding bones. It doesn’t contribute to any joints in the neck. Hence is correct statement.

 

Option B. The hyoid bone is anatomically connected to the thyroid cartilage by the thyrohyoid membrane. This connection plays a role in the movement and function of the larynx and pharynx. Hence B is also correct statement.

 

Options C. The hyoid bone is located in the front part of the neck and lies at the base of the mandible, above the thyroid cartilage. It is positioned in the anterior midline, which means it's centrally located at the front of the neck. C is also correct statement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  •  The greater horn of the hyoid bone actually develops from the third pharyngeal arch, not the second. The second pharyngeal arch contributes to the formation of other structures in the neck, but not the greater horn of the hyoid bone.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 14

questions.text: Muscle derived from First Pharyngeal Arch:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Mylohyoid

 

Option C:

 

  • Nerve of the first pharyngeal arch is Mandibular nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The buccinator muscle is derived from the second pharyngeal arch. It is innervated by facial nerve.

 

Option B: The stylopharyngeus muscle is derived from the third pharyngeal arch, not the first. This muscle is innervated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (cranial nerve IX), which is associated with the third arch.

 

Option D: The hyoglossus muscle is not derived from the first pharyngeal arch. Hyoglossus muscle is innervated by Hypoglossal Nerve and is derived from Occipital somites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The mylohyoid muscle is indeed derived from the first pharyngeal arch.
  • It forms the floor of the oral cavity and is innervated by the mandibular branch of the trigeminal nerve. The first pharyngeal arch is primarily associated with the trigeminal nerve.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of Human Embryology, First Edition. Yogesh Sontakke Pg 97.

questions.text: A 21-years-old patient Suyash came to OPD with history of fall on hand. Now he is having pain at hand region. X ray of patient is given. Which of the following joint has been shown in his X-ray?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid Joint.

 

Option C:

 

  • The wrist joint, or radiocarpal joint, is categorized as an ellipsoid joint.
  • Ellipsoid joints allow for movements in two planes, primarily flexion and extension, as well as abduction and adduction, but they do not permit axial rotation.
  • In the case of the wrist joint, it permits flexion and extension of the hand, as well as side-to-side movements (abduction and adduction) without allowing for rotation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hinge Joints, such as the elbow joint, primarily allow for flexion and extension movements in one plane.

 

Option B. Ball-and-Socket Joints, like the hip joint, allow for a wide range of motion, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation.

 

Option D. Saddle Joints, such as the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for movements in multiple directions, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wrist joint (radiocarpal joint) is classified as an ellipsoid joint, primarily allowing flexion, extension, and side-to-side movements without axial rotation.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy Upper limb and Thorax Vishram Singh 3rd edition pg. 153

questions.text: Match the correct pair:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 1- b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

 

1. Pressure Epiphysis:

 

  • Pressure epiphyses are regions of long bones where growth occurs due to the pressure applied to the epiphyseal plate, i.e. ends of long bones.
  • Growth is a result of compression forces.
  • Example: The  proximal and distal end of the femur/humerus is a pressure epiphysis.
  • During childhood and adolescence, the weight-bearing activities apply pressure on this epiphysis, allowing for bone elongation.

 

2. Traction Epiphysis:

 

  • Traction epiphyses are areas in long bones where growth happens in response to pulling or traction forces on the epiphyseal plate.
  • These forces are typically exerted by tendons or muscles attached to the bone.
  • Example: Tubercles of humerus or trochanters of femur.
  • The action of the patellar tendon, connected to the tibial tuberosity, leads to traction forces that promote bone growth.

 

3. Atavistic Epiphysis:

 

  • Atavistic epiphyses are secondary centers of ossification that are rare and may resemble ancestral bone structures.
  • They are considered vestigial.
  • Example: Coracoid process of scapula or os trigonum of talus or the presence of an additional epiphysis in the elbow joint that is not typically seen in modern humans would be considered an atavistic epiphysis.

 

4. Aberrant Epiphysis:

 

  • Aberrant epiphyses are anomalous growth centers or irregularities in bone development that deviate from the usual patterns.
  • Example: An individual with an extra epiphyseal center in the metacarpal bone, not commonly observed in the general population, would have an aberrant epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Diagrammatic presentation:

 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

choices.text: In the Lacunae of Osteons
In the Trabeculae of Osteons

questions.text: In which structure osteoclasts and osteoblasts are found?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) In the Periosteum

 

Option A.

 

  • The periosteum is a dense layer of vascular connective tissue enveloping the bones except at the surfaces of the joints.
  • This layer is crucial for bone growth and repair, as these cells are actively involved in bone remodeling.
  • The membrane around bones houses the bone forming cells (Osteoblasts) and the bone resorbing cells (Osteoclasts).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. In the Haversian Canals: Haversian canals are a series of tubes around narrow channels formed by lamellae, found in the osteon of compact bone. While Haversian canals contain blood vessels and nerves, they are not the primary location for osteoblasts and osteoclasts.

 

Option C. In the Lacunae of Osteons: Lacunae are small spaces within the osteon that contain osteocytes, which are mature bone cells. Osteoclasts and osteoblasts are not typically found in the lacunae. The lacunae primarily house osteocytes.

 

Option D. In the Trabeculae of Osteons: They are the spongy parts of bone that provide structural support and are found in the interior of bones. While trabeculae are involved in the bone remodeling process, osteoclasts and osteoblasts are more active in the periosteum and endosteum than within the trabeculae themselves.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The periosteum is a dense layer of vascular connective tissue enveloping the bones except at the surfaces of the joints. Both osteoblasts and osteoclasts are found in the periosteum. This layer is crucial for bone growth and repair, as these cells are actively involved in bone remodelling.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 71

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a muscle with a "Strap-like with Tendinous intersections" Fiber Arrangement, characterized by Uniform Width and Parallel Fibers?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Rectus Abdominis

 

Explanation:

 

Option B:

 

  • A "Strap-like" muscle, such as the Rectus Abdominis, is characterized by Uniform Width and Parallel muscle fibers running along the long axis of the muscle.
  • The rectus abdominis is a prominent abdominal muscle that provides stability and support to the anterior abdominal wall.
  • Its strap-like arrangement is well-suited for maintaining abdominal posture and assisting in various movements such as trunk flexion and stabilization.
  • It is having ribbon like parallel arrangement and also in between tendinous intersections as shown in image:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "Strap-like" muscle fiber arrangement, exemplified by the rectus abdominis, features uniform width and parallel fibers along the muscle's long axis, providing stability and support to the abdominal wall.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123

choices.text: The Palms of the Hands are facing Posteriorly.
The Feet are dorsiflexed at the ankles.

questions.text: Concept of “Anatomical Position” is very essential for all kind of operative procedure and to understand and publish the articles.  About anatomical position, which of the following statements is true?
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) The Thumbs are oriented Laterally.

 

This question is about the basic anatomical position of the human body.

 

Option B. The thumbs are indeed oriented laterally. This is a defining characteristic of the anatomical position, and it helps provide consistency in anatomical descriptions.

 

  • The anatomical position is a standardized reference posture used in anatomical and all medical & surgical descriptions.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The palms of the hands are facing anteriorly, not posteriorly. This allows for a clear view of the anatomical structures of the body.

 

Option C. The feet are not dorsiflexed at the ankles in the anatomical position. Instead, they are in a neutral position, with the toes pointing forward.

 

Option D. The elbows are not fully flexed; they are extended in the anatomical position but not fully. This extension allows for accurate descriptions of the upper limb’s anatomical relationships.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the anatomical position, the thumbs are oriented laterally. This position serves as a standardized reference for describing the location and orientation of anatomical structures in the human body.

 

Ref: BD Chaurasia’s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7th edition, Page no- 11, 12

choices.text: The Flexing of the arm with respect to the Forearm around the Elbow.
The Swivelling of the foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions.
The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.
The Rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a Cone Shape.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.

 

Option C:

 

  • Supination: Upward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).
  • Pronation: Downward rotation of hand in semi flexed elbow (Mid- prone position).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Flexing of the Arm with Respect to the Forearm around the Elbow: This describes flexion and extension, not pronation or supination. Flexion refers to decreasing the angle between the forearm and arm, while extension is increasing this angle.

 

 

Option B. The Swivelling of the Foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions: This is describing inversion and eversion of the foot. Inversion involves turning the sole of the foot inward, while eversion is turning it outward. These movements occur at the ankle and subtalar joints.

 

 

Option D. The Rotation at the Shoulder that Causes the Arm to Describe a Cone Shape: This is describing circumduction, a circular movement of the limb that combines flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. It is not specific to pronation or supination.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Twisting of the Wrist While the Elbow is Held Motionless: This correctly describes pronation and supination. These movements occur primarily at the radioulnar joint. In pronation, the radius rotates over the ulna so the palm faces downward. In supination, the radius and ulna are parallel, and the palm faces upward.

 

Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3rd Edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 134

questions.text: Which type of joint allows for rotational movement of the forearm, specifically allowing pronation and supination?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pivot Joint.

 

Option C:

 

  • The Upper and lower (superior & inferior) Radioulnar Joints are classified as a Pivot Joint. This type of joint allows for rotational movement around a central axis, facilitating pronation (turning the palm downward) and supination (turning the palm upward) of the forearm.
  • The pivot joint between the radius and ulna allows these bones to move independently during pronation and supination, which is important for activities like turning a doorknob or using a screwdriver.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hinge joints, such as the elbow joint, permit movement primarily in one plane (flexion and extension) and do not allow for the rotational movement seen in pronation and supination.

 

Option B. Ball-and-socket joints, like the hip joint, allow for a wide range of motion in multiple planes and are not involved in the specific rotational movements of the middle radioulnar joint.

 

Option D. Saddle joints, such as the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for movements in multiple directions, including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and circumduction, but they do not primarily facilitate pronation and supination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The  upper and lower (superior & inferior) radioulnar joint is a pivot joint that enables rotational movements of the forearm, specifically pronation and supination. 

 

Middle radioulnar joint is fibrous and it aids in weight transmission from radius to ulna

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 93

questions.text: A 33-year-old male presented to ENT OPD with infection of his external ear. During examination the doctor inserted a speculum into his external auditory canal close to the posterior wall. The patient suddenly fainted. Irritation of which of the following nerves could have caused the patient to faint?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vagus Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • Vagus nerves innervate the posterior wall of the external auditory canal. Its stimulation resulted in vasovagal syncope. Vagal stimulation leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The vestibulocochlear nerve is responsible for hearing and balance. Irritation of this nerve could potentially cause vertigo or hearing changes, but it is unlikely to cause syncope. It is concerned with hearing and equilibrium and not related to cutaneous sensation

 

Option C. The trigeminal nerve is primarily responsible for facial sensation and motor functions associated with mastication. While it does provide sensory innervation to parts of the ear, irritation of the trigeminal nerve is more likely to cause pain rather than fainting. The auriculotemporal branch from the mandibular division of trigeminal nerve supplies most of the external auditory canal except the posterior wall

 

Option D. The glossopharyngeal nerve has various functions, including sensation in the throat and back of the tongue, as well as some ear structures. The glossopharyngeal nerve supplies the inner aspect of the tympanic membrane. However, its stimulation is less likely to cause fainting compared to the vagus nerve. The glossopharyngeal nerve is more commonly associated with the gag reflex and swallowing functions.Top of Form

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • It innervates various structures in the head and neck, including parts of the ear. Stimulation of the vagus nerve, particularly in sensitive individuals, can lead to a vasovagal reflex. This reflex can cause a sudden decrease in heart rate and blood pressure, leading to fainting. The insertion of a speculum into the external auditory canal, especially if it is close to the posterior wall, could stimulate the auricular branch of the vagus nerve, triggering this response.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg  411

questions.text: Identify the VAGUS nerve in the given image:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) C

 

Option C:

 

Vagus lies within carotid sheath, between and behind the carotid arteries and internal jugular vein in carotid triangle

 

The marked structure in the given image are:

 

  1. Recurrent laryngeal nerve

  2. Cervical part of the sympathetic trunk

  3. Vagus nerve

  4. Trunks of brachial plexus

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Recurrent laryngeal nerve runs in the trachea esophageal groove. It supplies all muscles of larynx except cricothyroid that is innervated by external laryngeal nerve.

 

Option B. Cervical part of the sympathetic trunk lies on the posterior aspect of the carotid sheath, whereas ansa cervicalis lies on the anterior wall of the carotid sheath.

 

Option D. Trunks of brachial plexus lies in the posterior triangle between scalenus anterior and scalenus medius.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vagus lies within carotid sheath, between and behind the carotid arteries and internal jugular vein in carotid triangle.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 178

questions.text: A 57-year-old man underwent parotidectomy following which he complained that there was loss of sensation while shaving. Which nerve is affected most?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Greater Auricular Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The skin over the parotid gland/angle of mandible is innervated by great auricular nerve branch from cervical plexus.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Auriculotemporal nerve is a branch of the mandibular nerve (CN V3) and provides sensory innervation to the ear and temporal region of the scalp. While it is in the vicinity of the surgical site, the auriculotemporal nerve primarily innervates the area around the ear and the temple, not the lower face or jawline where shaving typically occurs.

 

Option C. The Mandibular nerve is the third division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V3) and provides sensory innervation to the lower lip, lower part of the face, and motor innervation to the muscles of mastication.

 

Although it is a major nerve in the area, its sensory distribution is more focused on the lower lip and chin rather than the area typically affected by shaving.

 

Option D. The Facial nerve (CN VII) is primarily a motor nerve, controlling muscles of facial expression. It also carries some sensory fibers and taste fibers but does not provide general sensation to the face. Damage to the facial nerve would more likely result in muscle weakness or paralysis (like an inability to close the eye or smile), not a loss of sensation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Greater Auricular nerve, a branch of the cervical plexus (arising from C2 and C3), provides sensory innervation to the skin over the parotid gland, the angle of the jaw, and the earlobe.

  • This nerve's sensory distribution includes the lower part of the face around the angle of the jaw, which is a common area for shaving.

  • Damage to this nerve during parotidectomy could lead to loss of sensation in this area, aligning with the patient's complaint.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 88

questions.text: What is the typical fiber arrangement of lumbrical muscles in the hand?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1st & 2nd Lumbricals – Unipennate, 3rd & 4th Lumbricals - Bipennate

 

Option A:

 

  • 1st & 2nd Lumbrical muscles in the hand typically exhibit a "unipennate" arrangement, where muscle fibers run along one side of the tendon.
  • This arrangement allows for precise control of finger flexion and extension.
  • Lumbricals originate from the flexor digitorum profundus tendons and have muscle fibers running unilaterally along one side of the tendons.
  • 3rd & 4th Lumbrical muscles in the hand typically exhibit a "bipennate" arrangement, where muscle fibers run along both sides of the tendon.
  • Among the given options A is best matching

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. 1st & 2nd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 3rd & 4th Lumbricals – Unipennate: It is just opposite of nature of lumbricals hence it is not the answer.

 

Option C. 1st & 3rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 2nd & 4th Lumbricals – Unipennate: It is also not matching according to direction of muscle fibres of lumbricals.

 

Option D. It is indicating that 2nd & 3rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 1st & 4th Lumbricals – Unipennate which is also incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • 1st & 2nd Lumbrical muscles in the hand typically exhibit a "Unipennate" arrangement, while 3rd & 4th Lumbrical muscles shows "Bipennate" arrangement. 
  • It is very important group of muscle because it is responsible for proper gripping by fingers & hand.

 

Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 147

choices.text: Right Sternocleidomastoid is involved in the above case scenario
Sternocleidomastoid is supplied by Spinal Accessory Nerve
Internal Jugular Vein lies in the space between the two heads of Sternocleidomastoid
Midpoint of Anterior border of Sternocleidomastoid is called Nervepoint of the neck

questions.text: The mother of a 10-month-old female child noticed that her daughter held her head in a tilted manner. She brought her to the pediatrician. On examination it was noticed that the head of the girl was tilted towards the right shoulder and her face was turned towards left and upwards. History revealed that the mother had a difficult labour and baby was delivered using forceps during which baby suffered soft tissue injury in the neck. Which of the following statements is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Midpoint of anterior border of sternocleidomastoid is called nervepoint of the neck

 

  • Midpoint of the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid is called nervepoint of the neck.
  • The nerves related are spinal accessory, supraclavicular, great auricular, lesser occipital and transverse cervical cutaneous nerve of neck.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The described head position (tilt towards the right shoulder and face turned to the left and upwards) suggests involvement of the right sternocleidomastoid muscle. This muscle's contraction would tilt the head towards the affected side (right) and rotate it to the opposite side (left).

 

Option B. The sternocleidomastoid muscle is innervated by the spinal accessory nerve (cranial nerve XI).

 

Option C. The internal jugular vein lies deep to the confluence of two heads of sternocleidomastoid muscle. Sternocleidomastoid muscle overlaps the Internal jugular vein superficially. The posterior belly of digastric and superior belly of omohyoid also cross over the Internal jugular vein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The "nerve point of the neck," also known as Erb's point, is not located at the midpoint of the anterior border of the sternocleidomastoid.
  • It is typically located at the posterior border of the sternocleidomastoid, around the midpoint of its length.
  •  This point is significant because several important nerves (including the spinal accessory nerve, branches of the cervical plexus, and the supraclavicular nerves) are located superficially here.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 449

questions.text: Which type of joint is characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue that tightly holds adjacent cranial bones together, allowing minimal to no movement?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sutural Joint.

 

Option D:

 

Sutural Joints, also known as sutures, are fibrous joints found in the skull where adjacent cranial bones are held together by fibrous connective tissue. These joints provide stability and serve as sutures for the cranial bones. Sutural joints allow minimal to no movement and are important for protecting the brain and maintaining the shape of the skull.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Synovial joints, like the knee or shoulder joint, have a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid and allow for a wide range of movements.

 

Option B. Cartilaginous joints, such as the pubic symphysis, are characterized by the presence of cartilage and allow limited movement.

 

Option C. Ball-and-socket joints, like the hip joint, allow for a wide range of motion in multiple planes, which is not characteristic of sutural joints.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Sutural joints are fibrous joints, found in the skull that provide stability and minimal to no movement. 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 89

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chronic hip pain. On X-ray, you observe a bony projection extending from the femoral neck. There are several normal projections from bone which can mimic such clinical situation. Among these which of the following is NOT a projection from a bone surface?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Trabeculae

 

A trabeculae (plural trabeculae) is the internal bony structure of spongy (cancellous) bone.

 

Option A. Trochanter - It is a large, irregularly shaped projection found on the femur.

 

Option B. Tubercle - It is a small, rounded projection on a bone.

 

Option D. Tuberosity - It  is a large, rounded projection on a bone.

 

Educational objective:

  • Trabeculae are not projections but rather the small, beam-like structures found in spongy bone. They are found within the interior of bones, such as in the epiphyses of long bones.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2nd edition, Vishram singh, pg. 18

choices.text: Superior Tonsillar Artery
Inferior Tonsillar Artery
Anterior Tonsillar Artery
Posterior Tonsillar Artery

questions.text: Principal Artery of Palatine Tonsil?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Inferior Tonsillar Artery

 

Option B: The inferior tonsillar branch from facial artery is the principal artery to palatine tonsil.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Superior tonsillar is branch from descending palatine artery (maxillary artery)

 

Option C: Anterior tonsillar is branch from dorsal lingual artery (lingual artery)

 

Option D: Posterior tonsillar branches arise from facial artery ascending palatine branch and ascending pharyngeal artery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The palatine tonsil, located in the oropharynx, receives its blood supply from several arteries, with the principal artery being the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.
     
  • This branch is often referred to as the inferior tonsillar artery, although this specific naming can vary in different texts. The importance of the tonsillar branch arises from its direct contribution to the vascular supply of the tonsil. Here's a detailed explanation:

 

  1. Facial Artery: The facial artery is a major branch of the external carotid artery. As it courses upwards along the side of the face, it gives off several branches that supply various structures, including the palatine tonsil.
     
  2. Tonsillar Branch: The tonsillar branch typically arises near the upper border of the tonsil. It enters the tonsillar fossa from below, often after giving off branches to the adjacent pharyngeal muscles and other nearby structures. Upon reaching the tonsil, the tonsillar branch penetrates the tonsillar capsule and provides the primary blood supply to the tonsil.
     
  3. Collateral Supply: Although the tonsillar branch of the facial artery is the principal artery, the tonsil also receives collateral blood supply from other arteries, including:
     
  • Ascending Palatine Artery: A branch of the facial artery that ascends on the pharyngeal wall and supplies the tonsil from its posterior aspect.
     
  • Dorsal Lingual Branches: From the lingual artery, supplying the base of the tongue and contributing to the tonsil's vascularization.
  • Ascending Pharyngeal Artery: A branch of the external carotid artery, contributing to the vascular supply of the pharynx and tonsils.
     
  • Lesser Palatine Arteries: Branches from the descending palatine artery (itself a branch of the maxillary artery), supplying the soft palate and tonsils.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 153

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with unexplained fatigue and pallor. Laboratory tests reveal low hemoglobin levels and a decreased red blood cell count. Further evaluation shows a decrease in erythrocyte production in the bone marrow. Which of the following is most likely the content of the medullary canal of a long bone responsible for erythropoiesis in adults?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Marrow

 

Option C –

 

  • It is a Soft, Fatty tissue found inside the Medullary Canal.
  • There are Two types of Bone Marrow:
    • Red Marrow, which is involved in Blood Cell production
    • Yellow Marrow, which primarily stores Fat.
  • The Medullary canal, also known as the Medullary Cavity, is a central feature of Long Bones. It is responsible for Erythropoiesis.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Trabeculae:

 

  • Trabeculae are the small, needle-like pieces of bone that provide structural support within spongy bone.
  • They are primarily found in the ends of long bones (epiphyses) and within the interior of other bones, not typically within the medullary canal.

 

Option B. Lamellae:

 

  • They are thin layers of bone tissue that make up the concentric rings in compact bone.
  • They are a part of the osteon or Haversian system, which is the structural unit of compact bone.

 

Option D. Osteoblasts and Osteoclasts:

 

  • Osteoblasts are cells that form new bone tissue, and osteoclasts are cells that break down old bone tissue.
  • These cells are found throughout the bone, particularly in areas of bone remodeling.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Marrow –

 

  • It is a soft, fatty tissue found inside the medullary canal.
  • There are two types of bone marrow:
    • Red marrow, which is involved in blood cell production
    • Yellow marrow, which primarily stores fat.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 73

questions.text: In the context of young bones, which part is primarily responsible for longitudinal growth?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Epiphyseal plate

 

It is present between metaphysis and epiphysis in the growing bone. Once the complete fusion of this plate takes place the growth also stops.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Diaphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis.
  • It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.

 

Option B. Epiphysis

 

  • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis.
  • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability, it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.

 

Option C. Metaphysis 

 

  • Metaphysis is the part of the bone between diaphysis and growth plate in the growing bone and in the adult bone it lies between diaphysis and epiphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

choices.text: The skin area between the upper lip, and the side of the nose is called dangerous zone of face
Interference with a boil by squeezing or pricking it can lead to spread of the infection and thrombosis of the facial vein
The facial vein communicates with the cavernous sinus via the superior and inferior ophthalmic veins
Facial vein lies immediately in front of and has a tortuous course similar to facial artery

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who had joined as a first-year student in a visual communication course was recently not happy with the pimples that developed over cheeks. She visited her dermatologist who noticed the severe acne on the face of that girl even before she complained. On examination, it was found that a small abscess was present just above her upper lip below the nose on the right side of her face. Her dermatologist gave her antibiotics and strictly warned her not to press the abscess. Which of the following facts concerning this patient is not correct?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Facial vein lies immediately in front of and has a tortuous course similar to facial artery

 

Option D:

 

  • Facial vein lies behind the facial artery and has a straighter course.

  • Facial vein communicates with the cavernous sinus via the angular vein and deep facial vein.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The area described is often referred to as the "dangerous area of the face" due to its venous drainage pattern. Infections in this area can potentially spread to the cranial cavity because of the venous connections.

 

 

Option B. Manipulating a boil or abscess in the facial area, particularly in the dangerous zone, can cause the infection to spread, leading to complications like thrombosis of the facial vein.

 

Option C. The facial vein has connections with the cavernous sinus through the ophthalmic veins. This anatomical feature is significant because it provides a pathway for infection to spread from the face to the intracranial structures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Although the facial vein is closely associated with the facial artery, it does not have a tortuous course like the facial artery.

  • The facial artery is known for its tortuosity, which allows it to accommodate facial movements without kinking. In contrast, the facial vein has a relatively straighter course.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 500

choices.text: Sacroiliac Joint and Temporomandibular Joint Hip Joint

questions.text: Which two joints are responsible for the nodding and shaking movements of the head, respectively?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Atlanto-Occipital Joint and atlanto-axial

 

Option A:

 

  • The Atlanto-Occipital Joint is located between the atlas (C1 vertebra) and the occipital bone at the base of the skull. This joint allows for nodding movements of the head, such as when you nod "yes."
  • The Atlanto-Axial Joint is located between the atlas (C1 vertebra) and the axis (C2 vertebra). This joint is responsible for the rotational movement of the head, allowing for shaking movements, as in shaking your b.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The sternoclavicular joint and costovertebral joint are not responsible for the primary movements of the head.

 

Option C. The sacroiliac joint and hip joint are located in the pelvis and are not involved in head movements.

 

Option D. The glenohumeral joint is the shoulder joint, and the temporomandibular joint is the jaw joint, neither of which is primarily responsible for the movements of the head.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The atlanto-axial joint is responsible for shaking movements and the atlanto-occipital joint for nodding movements in head motion. 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 93

questions.text: Which of the following bone of the skull articulates to form a synovial joint?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The Mandible

 

Option C:

 

  • The Ramus of the mandible articulates with the temporal bone at the mandibular fossa.
  • The joint is freely moveable, allowing us to chew and speak.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Sphenoid

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, forming part of the cranial floor.
  • It does not form a synovial joint; rather, it articulates with other cranial bones through sutures.

 

Option B. The Maxilla

 

  • It forms the upper jaw and is involved in forming the roof of the mouth, floors of the orbits, and sides and floor of the nasal cavity.
  • The maxilla is fused to other bones of the face and does not form a synovial joint.

 

Option D. The Hyoid

 

  • It is a U-shaped bone in the neck that supports the tongue and provides attachment for muscles associated with swallowing.
  • It is not directly attached to other bones but is suspended by ligaments and muscles.
  • The hyoid does not form a synovial joint.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mandible or lower jawbone, forms a synovial joint with the temporal bone of the skull known as the Temporo-Mandibular Joint (TMJ). It is a bicondylar type of synovial joint that allows for the movement necessary for chewing, speaking, and other mouth movements.

 

Ref: Textbook of Anatomy regional and clinical head, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 17

choices.text: This condition is diagnosed as Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus
The Ophthalmic nerve is the largest division of the Trigeminal Nerve
The Ophthalmic nerve divides into Lacrimal, Frontal and Nasociliary Nerve
The Trigeminal Ganglion is located in the Middle Cranial Fossa

questions.text: A 56-year-old male visited the surgery OPD with complaints of fever, burning sensation on forehead and around left eye vesicles over his upper face, he also said that these lesions are painful. On examination it was found that these painful vesicles were distributed along the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Which of the following statements is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The Ophthalmic nerve is the largest division of the Trigeminal Nerve

 

Option B:

 

  • The ophthalmic nerve is the smallest division of the trigeminal nerve

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Herpes Zoster Ophthalmicus is characterized by painful vesicular eruptions on the face, particularly in the distribution of the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve, as described in the patient's symptoms.

 

 

Option C. The ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve branches into the lacrimal, frontal, and nasociliary nerves, which provide sensory innervation to different parts of the upper face and scalp.

 

Option D. The trigeminal ganglion, which is the sensory ganglion of the trigeminal nerve, is indeed located in the middle cranial fossa of the skull.

 

Do not confuse this ganglia with the parasympathetic ganglia. The parasympathetic ganglia are located outside the cranial cavity but the ganglia of trigeminal is sensory and is located in the cranial cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The largest division of the trigeminal nerve (CN V) is actually the mandibular division (V3). The ophthalmic division (V1) is the smallest of the three divisions of the trigeminal nerve.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 501

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of facial pain and pressure, a persistent low-grade fever, and nasal congestion for the past two weeks. He also mentions postnasal drip and a reduced sense of smell. He denies any recent upper respiratory tract infections, but he recalls having similar symptoms in the past during allergy seasons. This clinical case is associated with which of the following pair of bone and its type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ethmoid – Pneumatic Bone

 

Option D:

 

  • This is typical case of sinusitis. Sinusitis occurs due to inflammation of para nasal air sinuses which are located within pneumatic bones.
  • Ethmoid is classical example of pneumatic bone among given options.
  • Pneumatic bones are bones that contain air-filled spaces or cavities known as pneumatic cells.
  • These air-filled spaces are connected to the respiratory system and serve various functions, including reducing bone weight and contributing to the resonance of the voice.
  • The ethmoid bone, located in the skull, contains multiple pneumatic cells called ethmoidal air cells or sinuses.
  • These air cells are crucial for the sense of smell and also help reduce the overall weight of the skull.
  • E.g. Maxilla, Frontal, Sphenoid, and Ethmoid bones and a part of the Mastoid process of the Temporal Bone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Mandible is a flat bone of lower jaw and is not considered a pneumatic bone.

 

Option B. Occipital is a flat bone of does not contain pneumatic cells.

 

Option C. Vertebrae are the bones of the spine and do not typically contain pneumatic cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ethmoid bone is classified as a pneumatic bone due to the presence of ethmoidal air cells. 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: During embryonic development, the aortic arches play a crucial role in forming the major arteries of the head and neck region. The third aortic arch contributes to the formation of which important blood vessel?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Common carotid artery

 

Option A: The third aortic arch contributes to the formation of the common carotid artery, which later gives rise to the internal and external carotid arteries.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: While the internal carotid artery is a branch of the common carotid artery, it primarily arises from the common carotid artery rather than directly from the third aortic arch.

 

Option C: The external carotid artery is also a branch of the common carotid artery but does not directly arise from the third aortic arch.

 

Option D: The vertebral artery arises from the subclavian artery, not from the aortic arches.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The third aortic arch gives rise to the common carotid artery on each side, which later divides into the internal and external carotid arteries.

 

Ref: Larsen’s Human Embryology, 6th Edition, Page no- 433

questions.text:
In the anatomical arrangement of intermuscular spaces such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, anatomical snuff box, etc., what primarily forms the roof of these spaces?

 

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia
  3. Subcutaneous fat, cutaneous nerves and vessels
  4. Deep fascia
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1,2,3,4

 

Explanation:

 

  • Intermuscular spaces, like the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box, have a characteristic anatomical arrangement.
  • The roof of these intermuscular space is formed layer by layer from following structures.
  1. Skin - In this layer hair & skin appendages are present.
  2. Superficial fascia - In this layer subcutaneous fat , cutaneous nerves and vessels are present.
  3. Deep fascia - It is a dense, fibrous connective tissue layer, loaded with collagen, that surrounds and separates muscle groups, providing structural support and defining the boundaries of these anatomical regions.

 

From superficial to deep the layers are present as follows

  1. Skin
  2. Superficial fascia along with contents 
  3. Deep fascia
     

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The primary structures forming the roof of intermuscular spaces, such as the cubital fossa, femoral triangle, and anatomical snuff box are skin, superficial fascia & deep fascia along with their contents. 

 

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, International Edition, Page no - 872

BD Chaurasia’s Human Anatomy, 9th Edition, Volume 1, Page no - 107, 108

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with a suspected fracture of the tibia. On imaging studies, blood vessels located within the compact bone are most critical for providing nourishment to the deeper regions of the bone? Where are these blood vessels located within compact bone?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) In the Central Canal

 

Option D.

 

  • The vessels supplying to bone runs within central canal (or Haversian canal) of bone.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. In the Canaliculi:

 

  • Blood vessels are not typically found in the canaliculi of compact bone.
  • Canaliculi are tiny channels or tunnels that allow for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between osteocytes and blood vessels.
  • While they facilitate communication between cells and nearby blood vessels, the blood vessels themselves are not located within the canaliculi.

 

Option B. In the Periosteum:

 

  • Blood vessels are indeed found in the periosteum.
  • The periosteum is a dense connective tissue membrane that covers the outer surface of bones and contains blood vessels, nerves, and other structures.

 

Option C. In the Lacunae:

 

  • Blood vessels are not typically found within the lacunae.
  • Lacunae are small spaces within the bone matrix where osteocytes reside.
  • These spaces house bone cells but not blood vessels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Blood vessels are primarily found in the central canal, also known as the Haversian canal or osteonic canal.
  • The central canal runs longitudinally through the center of each osteon and contains blood vessels, nerves, and connective tissue.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

choices.text: The relationship between muscle innervation and joint function.
The correlation between blood supply and organ health.
The connection between the nerve supplying a joint and the muscles moving the joint.
The relationship between the size of a muscle and its strength.

questions.text: Hilton's Law of Anatomy is most closely associated with which principle?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The connection between the nerve supplying a joint and the muscles moving the joint.

 

  • Hilton's Law of Anatomy, formulated by John Hilton, is a principle that highlights the relationship between the nerve supplying a joint and the muscles responsible for moving that joint.
  • According to this law, the same nerves that supply a joint also innervate the muscles moving that joint and the skin overlying it.
  • This principle is essential for understanding the sensory and motor functions of joints, muscles, and skin in clinical practice.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The relationship between muscle innervation and joint function is not the primary focus of Hilton's Law.

 

Option B. The correlation between blood supply and organ health is unrelated to Hilton's Law.

 

Option D. The relationship between the size of a muscle and its strength is not a direct aspect of Hilton's Law.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Hilton's Law of Anatomy emphasizes the connection between the nerve supplying a joint and the muscles responsible for moving the joint.

 

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, 42nd Edition, International Edition, Page no-104

BD Chaurasia’s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7th edition, Page no- 109

questions.text: Following thyroid surgery patient presented with hoarseness of voice, the nerve injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve

 

Option D:

 

  • Recurrent laryngeal accompanies the inferior thyroid artery and innervates all muscles of larynx except cricothyroid innervated by external laryngeal nerve.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The External Laryngeal Nerve is a branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve. It primarily innervates the cricothyroid muscle, which helps in the tension and lengthening of the vocal cords. Injury to this nerve may affect the quality of voice by altering the pitch, but it is less likely to cause hoarseness or significant voice changes compared to damage to the Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve.

 

Option B. This is also a branch of the Superior Laryngeal Nerve. The Internal Laryngeal Nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa above the vocal cords. An injury to this nerve might lead to sensory deficits but would not typically cause hoarseness, as it does not innervate vocal cord muscles.

 

Option C. The Superior Laryngeal Nerve, a branch of the Vagus Nerve (CN X), divides into the internal and external laryngeal nerves. While the external branch is involved in voice modulation, its injury typically does not cause hoarseness to the extent seen with Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Recurrent Laryngeal Nerve, a branch of the Vagus Nerve (CN X), innervates all the intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle. It is crucial for controlling the vocal cords.

  • Injury to this nerve can lead to paralysis or paresis of the vocal cords on the affected side, causing hoarseness or even aphonia (loss of voice). This is a well-known risk in thyroid surgery, particularly because of the nerve's proximity to the thyroid gland.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 408

questions.text: A patient presents with a sprained ankle following a sports injury. Which type of connective tissue structure is most commonly affected in ankle sprains?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ligaments

 

Option D:

 

  • Ankle sprains often involve the injury to ligaments.
  • Ligaments are tough, fibrous connective tissues that connect bone to bone, providing stability to joints.
  • In the case of an ankle sprain, the most commonly affected structures are the ligaments that support the ankle joint
  • Ligaments join bone to bone while tendons (and aponeuroses) join muscle to bone.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Aponeuroses - They are flat, broad tendinous sheets. They serve as a means for muscle attachment to the bones but are not directly involved in connecting bones at a joint.

 

Option B. Tendon - They are strong, fibrous connective tissues that connect muscles to bones. They help in transmitting the force generated by muscles to bones, causing movement.

 

Option C. Fasciculi - It refers to bundles of muscle fibers within a muscle. They are part of the muscle's internal structure and are involved in muscle contraction and force generation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ligaments are tough bands of fibrous connective tissue. They connect bones to other bones at a joint, providing stability and guiding joint movement.

 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 18

questions.text: Match the following according to the classification of arrangement of muscle fibres with their example for each type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1- b, 2- a, 3- d, 4- c 

 

Option D:

 

 

Explanation: Different types of arrangement of muscle fibres shown in image:

 

 

1. Fusiform Arrangement:

 

  • Muscle fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle.
  • Example: Biceps brachii

 

2. Pennate Arrangement:

 

  • Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.
  • Example: Rectus Femoris

 

3. Cruciate Arrangement:

 

  • Muscle fibres having 2 sets, which cross each other
  • Example: Sternocleidomastoid

 

4. Spiral/ Twisted:

 

  • Muscle fibres having only 1 set in which upper fibres runs down & lower fibres runs upside in between attachments.
  • Example: Latissimus Dorsi & Pectoralis Major

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Arrangement of muscle fibre direction - Biceps brachii shows Fusiform  arrangement, Rectus femoris shows Bipennate arrangement, Sternocleidomastoid shows Cruciate arrangement & Latissimus dorsi  shows Spiral arrangement.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123

questions.text: A 28-year-old male sustained head injury due to fall from his bike. CT brain showed extradural hematoma. The blood vessel injured is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Middle Meningeal Artery

 

Option C:

 

  • Rupture of middle meningeal vessels results in extradural haemorrhage

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The Middle Cerebral Artery is a major artery in the brain that supplies blood to lateral parts of the brain, including the lateral temporal and frontal lobes, and part of the parietal lobe. Injury to the Middle Cerebral Artery usually leads to an intracerebral hemorrhage or a subarachnoid hemorrhage, not an extradural hematoma. This artery is located deep within the brain tissue and is not typically involved in extradural bleedings.

 

Option B. Superior cerebral veins drain the cerebral hemispheres and empty into the superior sagittal sinus. While venous bleeding can occur due to head trauma, it is more likely to result in a subdural hematoma rather than an extradural one. The venous bleeding is usually slower than arterial bleeding and often occurs over a larger surface area.

 

Option D. The Accessory Meningeal Artery is a smaller artery that also supplies the meninges. While it could potentially be involved in an extradural bleed, it is much less likely than the Middle Meningeal Artery, given its smaller size and different anatomical course.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Anatomy: The Middle Meningeal Artery is a branch of the maxillary artery and runs between the skull and the dura mater.
  • Relation to Extradural Hematoma: This artery is the most commonly injured vessel in extradural hematomas, particularly when there is a fracture of the temporal bone, as it runs within the grooves on the inner surface of the skull.
  • Trauma can lead to its rupture, causing rapid bleeding and the formation of an extradural hematoma.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 313

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a plane synovial joint in the human body?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Costo-Transverse Joint.

 

Option D:

 

  • A plane synovial joint, also known as a Gliding Joint, allows for sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces.
  • The costo-transverse joint, found between the ribs and the transverse processes of the thoracic vertebrae, is an example of a plane synovial joint.
  • It allows for slight gliding movements and contributes to the flexibility and mobility of the rib cage during breathing.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The hip joint is a ball-and-socket synovial joint that permits a wide range of movements.

 

Option B. The knee joint is a modified hinge synovial joint that primarily allows flexion and extension along with slight rotation.

 

Option C. The elbow joint is a hinge synovial joint that primarily allows flexion and extension along with slight rotation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The plane synovial joint, or gliding joint, allows sliding or gliding movements between flat articular surfaces. 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 93

questions.text: Patient presented with a sagging face, asymmetrical smile, facial muscle tone with drooping of left angle of mouth, eyelid with drooping cornersand inability to blow properly. Which Nerve is involved in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Facial Nerve

 

Option A:

 

  • The patient's symptoms of a sagging face, asymmetrical smile, drooping of the left angle of the mouth, eyelid drooping, and inability to blow properly are indicative of nerve involvement affecting facial muscles.

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. The Maxillary nerve is the second branch of the Trigeminal nerve (CN V). It is primarily a sensory nerve for the mid-facial region, including the lower eyelid, upper lip, and cheek. While this nerve is responsible for sensation in areas of the face, it does not control facial muscle movements. Therefore, its involvement would not lead to muscle weakness or paralysis, making it an unlikely cause of the patient's symptoms.

 

Option C. The Mandibular nerve is the third branch of the Trigeminal nerve (CN V). It has both sensory and motor functions, the latter mainly for the muscles of mastication (chewing). Though this nerve has motor functions, these are largely restricted to the muscles of mastication. It does not control the muscles responsible for facial expressions, so it's unlikely to be the cause of the symptoms like drooping mouth and eyelid or asymmetrical smile.

 

Option D. The Ophthalmic nerve is the first branch of the Trigeminal nerve (CN V) and is primarily a sensory nerve for the upper part of the face, including the forehead, scalp, and upper eyelid. This nerve provides sensation to the upper facial region but does not control muscle movements. Thus, its dysfunction would not result in the muscular symptoms described in the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Facial nerve (CN VII) is responsible for motor control of most of the facial muscles. It controls movements such as blinking, smiling, frowning, and other expressions.

  • The symptoms described, such as asymmetrical smile, drooping of the mouth and eyelid, and difficulty in blowing, are classic signs of facial nerve palsy. This nerve's impairment leads to weakness or paralysis of the facial muscles on the affected side.

 

Injury to facial nerve produces LMN Bell’s palsy which presents with

 

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg. 393

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

 

Option D:

 

  • In this case knee cap bone Patella is involved, which is classical example of sesamoid bone.
  • Important Features of Sesamoid bone.

 

  1. Small and Ossified: Sesamoid bones are typically small, flat, and rounded bones that develop within tendons. They are typically composed of ossified (hardened) tissue.
  2. Location: They are commonly found near joints, especially in areas subject to significant mechanical stress, such as the hands, feet, and knees.
  3. Function: Sesamoid bones serve as pulleys, reducing friction and providing leverage for tendons as they pass over joints. They help improve joint function and protect tendons from excessive wear and tear.
  4. They ossify after the birth.
  5. These bones are having –
    • No Haversian canal.
    • No medullary cavity.
    • No periosteusm.

 

Examples of Sesamoid Bones in Body:

 

  1. Patella (Kneecap):

 

  • The largest sesamoid bone in the human body is the patella, which is located in the front of the knee joint.
  • It is ossified in tendon of quadriceps femoris.

 

  1. Pisiform:

 

  • It ossifies within tendon of flexor carpi ulnaris.
  • It is the last carpal bone to ossify.

 

  1. Fabella:
  • It is found in lateral head of gastrocnemius muscle.

 

  1. At Thumb (First Metacarpal):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are often present at the base of the thumb (first metacarpal bone), where they contribute to the flexibility and strength of thumb movements.

 

  1. At Foot (Metatarsophalangeal Joints):

 

  • Sesamoid bones are commonly found beneath the metatarsophalangeal joints of the foot, especially the first metatarsophalangeal joint near the big toe.
  • They assist in weight-bearing and movement of the foot during activities like walking and running.

 

Clinical Significance:

 

  • Understanding the presence and function of sesamoid bones is essential for healthcare professionals, as injuries or conditions related to these bones can impact joint mobility, stability, and overall musculoskeletal health.
  • X-ray Identification: Sesamoid bones are often visible on X-rays, and their presence and location can be important for diagnosing certain medical conditions, such as fractures or inflammation related to sesamoid bones.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Sphenoid –

 

  • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull, in the middle of the cranial floor.
  • It is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option B. Hyoid –

 

  • U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck that does not directly articulate with any other bone.
  • It serves as an anchoring structure for the tongue and muscles in the neck and throat but is not embedded within a tendon.

 

Option C. Ethmoid –

 

  • It is located between the eyes and at the roof of the nasal cavity.
  • It is part of the cranial floor and contributes to the medial wall of the orbit, the nasal septum, and the nasal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sesamoid: Sesamoid bones like patella are small, round bones that are embedded within tendons. They are found in locations where a tendon passes over a joint, such as the knee, hand, and foot. It helps to overcome compressive forces and modify pressure, reduce friction, and occasionally alter the direction of muscle pull.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents to the clinic with a persistent, dull pain in his left ear and a recent onset of a metallic taste in his mouth. He has a history of chronic ear infections but denies any recent infections or trauma. Otoscopic examination reveals no acute inflammation or infection in the external auditory canal or tympanic membrane. Given the patient's symptoms and history, which anatomical structure in the middle ear, if affected, could explain his symptoms?
