questions.solution:
Ans. B) Floor

 

Option B:

 

  • Tympanic branch of IX nerve is called Jacobson's nerve, it enters middle ear by piercing the floor -jugular fossa which lodges superior bulb of IJV

 

 

  • Jacobson's nerve, also known as the tympanic branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX), enters the middle ear cavity through a small canal in the floor of the middle ear, known as the tympanic canaliculus.
  • This nerve provides innervation to the mucosa of the middle ear and the mastoid air cells and participates in the formation of the tympanic plexus.
  • It also carries taste fibers from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, which can explain the metallic taste in the patient's mouth if the nerve is irritated or damaged.
  • The persistent dull ear pain without signs of acute infection could be related to chronic changes or irritation in the middle ear affecting Jacobson's nerve.
  • The other options (roof, anterior wall, and posterior wall) are not typical entry points for Jacobson's nerve into the middle ear and would not directly explain the combination of ear pain and altered taste sensation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Roof is formed by tegmen tympani and pierced by greater and lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Option C: Anterior wall -lower part -carotid canal and pierced by superior and inferior caroticotympanic nerves.

 

Option D: Posterior wall is related to the vertical course of facial nerve in its bony canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Jacobson's nerve, also known as the tympanic nerve, is a branch of the glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX). It carries parasympathetic fibers to the middle ear and is involved in the innervation of the mucosa of the middle ear, the mastoid air cells, and the Eustachian tube.
  • Jacobson's nerve enters the middle ear by piercing the floor of the tympanic cavity. It does so through a small canal known as the tympanic canaliculus, which is located near the promontory of the medial wall of the middle ear.
  • After entering the middle ear, the tympanic nerve contributes to the formation of the tympanic plexus on the surface of the promontory.
  • This plexus is involved in providing sensory innervation to the mucous membrane of the tympanic cavity and mastoid air cells, as well as contributing parasympathetic fibers to the otic ganglion via the lesser petrosal nerve.

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol. 3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 278

choices.text: Muscle Fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle.
Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.
Muscle Fibers encircle an opening or body cavity.
Muscle Fibers are arranged in a concentric circular pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the classification of muscle fibre arrangement known as "Pennate Arrangement"?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Muscle fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.

 

Explanation:

 

  • "Pennate Arrangement" refers to muscle fibers that are obliquely oriented to the tendon, creating a feather-like or fan-like pattern.
  • This arrangement provides a greater number of muscle fibers in a given cross-sectional area, allowing for more force generation.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The classification of "Pennate Arrangement" in Muscle Fibers involves Oblique orientation of fibers to the tendon, as seen in muscles like the Rectus Femoris.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123

choices.text: Paralysis of the right genioglossus muscle permitted the left genioglossus to pull the tongue forward and turned the tip to the right side
Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible
The vagus nerve descends in the neck between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein

At about the level of the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone the hypoglossal nerve turns forward and crosses the internal and external carotid arteries and the lingual artery to enter the tongue

questions.text: A 36-year-old auto driver was attacked by a mob over a family quarrel and received a stab wound at the front of the neck. He was rushed to the emergency department. The knife entrance wound was located on the right side of the neck just lateral to the tip of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone. During the physical examination the patient was asked to protrude his tongue, which deviated to the right. Which of the following statements would is incorrect regarding the physical signs in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Genioglossus originates from the lower genial tubercles of the mandible

 

Option B:

 

  • Genioglossus muscle originates from the superior genial tubercles situated on the inner surface of symphysis menti of mandible

 

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The genioglossus muscle is responsible for protruding the tongue. If the right genioglossus is paralyzed (due to injury to the right hypoglossal nerve), the left genioglossus would pull the tongue towards the left, causing the tip to deviate to the right side.

 

Option C. The Vagus Nerve (CN X) does indeed pass between the internal carotid artery and the internal jugular vein in its course in the neck.

 

Option D. The hypoglossal nerve turns anteriorly around the level of the greater cornu of the hyoid bone and crosses various structures, including the carotid arteries and the lingual artery, to enter the tongue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The genioglossus muscle actually originates from the superior genial tubercles of the mandible, not the lower. This error makes option B the incorrect statement.

Geniohyoid takes origin from lower genial tubercles.

 

Ref: Gray’s Anatomy 41st Edition Pg No 511

questions.text:
The spinal accessory nerve, crucial for motor function, innervates the sternocleidomastoid and trapezius muscles. Damage to this nerve can lead to shoulder weakness, inability to raise the arm above the head, shoulder droop, and difficulty in turning the head to the opposite side. It's often injured due to surgical procedures in the neck or trauma, resulting in characteristic physical findings and requiring targeted therapy for recovery. Spinal accessory nerve related to which of the following triangles:

 

  1. Occipital triangle
  2. Subclavian triangle
  3. Muscular triangle
  4. Carotid triangle
  5. Submental triangle
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 4

 

Option C:

 

  • The spinal accessory nerve enters the posterior triangle of the neck after emerging from the jugular foramen, runs superficially across the sternocleidomastoid muscle, and then descends to innervate the trapezius.

  • Its superficial path in this region makes it vulnerable to injury during surgical procedures in the neck, particularly those involving the lymph nodes.

 

 

Explanation:

 

  1. Occipital triangle

    • The occipital triangle is part of the posterior triangle of the neck, bordered by the sternocleidomastoid, trapezius, and the inferior belly of the omohyoid muscle. The spinal accessory nerve travels through this triangle, innervating the sternocleidomastoid muscle from its deep surface before crossing the triangle to reach the trapezius muscle. This makes the occipital triangle relevant to the spinal accessory nerve.

  2. Subclavian triangle

    • Also known as the supraclavicular triangle, this is the smaller division of the posterior triangle, located inferior to the occipital triangle. While the spinal accessory nerve runs in close proximity to this area, especially as it travels to the trapezius muscle, its primary course is not within this triangle.

  3. Muscular triangle

    • The muscular triangle is a region of the anterior triangle of the neck, containing muscles like the infrahyoid muscles, but it does not include the path of the spinal accessory nerve. The nerve does not travel through this triangle.

  4. Carotid triangle

    • The carotid triangle is part of the anterior triangle of the neck. The spinal accessory nerve does not traverse this triangle in its typical anatomical course, but it is located posterior to this triangle. The nerve's relationship to this triangle is clinically significant, particularly in surgeries involving the neck's lateral regions.

  5. Submental triangle

    • The submental triangle is another region of the anterior triangle, located under the chin. The spinal accessory nerve does not travel through this area.

 

Given these relationships, the correct answer is Option C. 1,4 (Occipital triangle and Carotid triangle)

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The spinal accessory nerve is most closely related to the occipital triangle due to its direct course through this area.

  • Spinal accessory nerve is related to carotid triangle (anterior triangle) and also occipital triangle (posterior triangle).

 

Ref: IB Singh Textbook of Anatomy Vol.3 Head and Neck, Neuroanatomy 7th Edition Pg 408

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a painful, swollen finger after accidentally slamming it in a door. On examination, there is tenderness and deformity of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. Which bone of the hand is most likely to be fractured in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Phalanges

 

Option D: Phalanges are the bones of the fingers which are injured in this case.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Short Bones:-

 

  • They are defined by their cuboidal shape and are primarily found in the wrist and ankle.
  • They are not the bones of the fingers.

 

Option B. Metacarpals

 

  • They are the five long bones located in the hand between the carpal bones and the fingers.
  • Each metacarpal corresponds to a digit of the hand, but they are not the bones within the fingers themselves.

 

Option C. Carpals

 

  • They are the eight small bones that make up the wrist, connecting the hand to the forearm.
  • They are arranged in two rows and contribute to the wrist's complex range of movements. However, they are not the bones of the fingers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phalanges:

 

  • They are the bones of the fingers (and toes).
  • Each finger has three phalanges - the proximal, middle, and distal phalanges, except for the thumb, which has only two (proximal and distal).
  • These bones provide the structural framework of the fingers, allowing for their extensive range of motion and dexterity.

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: Which type of joint is characterized by the presence of a cartilaginous pad or disc between the articulating bones and allows for limited movement?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary Cartilaginous Joint.

 

Option C:

 

  • A secondary cartilaginous joint, also known as a symphysis, is a type of joint where the articulating bones are connected by a fibrocartilaginous disc or pad.
  • These joints allow for limited movement and provide stability and shock absorption.
  • The pubic symphysis in the pelvic region and the intervertebral discs in the spine are examples of secondary cartilaginous joints.

 

Explanation:-

 

Option A. Suture joints are fibrous joints found in the skull, where the bones are tightly interlocked and allow for no movement.

 

Option B. Synovial joints, like the knee or shoulder joint, have a joint cavity filled with synovial fluid and allow for a wide range of movements.

 

Option D. Fibrous joints, such as sutures or syndesmoses, are characterized by dense fibrous connective tissue and do not allow significant movement.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The secondary cartilaginous joints are the joints with fibrocartilaginous disc, which allows the limited movement. 

 

Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 89
